label.name: The distribution of the error term gives insights ...
label.intro:
The distribution of the error term gives insights into whether there is more variability to account for in the model. We look at an example where we build up a model and see how the distribution of the error term improves. 

This example uses the following data with 5 variables and 2400 rows:


  • Yield (outcome)

  • Variety - 3 types of varieties

  • Soil type - 2 types of soil

  • Fertiliser level - concentration of fertiliser used

  • Field - field ID that the yield is in


We look at the yield variable, and can see it is normally distributed. This suggests that a linear model should be used. 




We fit a series of models to examine the distribution of the error term in the model.


Model 1

The first model fitted has one explanatory variable: Soil. We examine the output in a QQ-plot.

We expect this plot to display the points on the straight diagonal line. However, there is some deviation suggesting that there is variability in this model unaccounted for. 



Model 2: 

In the second model, we add Variety as well as Soil as the second explanatory variable.

When looking at the QQ-plot, the distribution of the error terms look a lot better now, suggesting this model is a better fit than Model 1. However, there is still some deviation. It might be worth adding a third variable to see if it fits the line better.



Model 3:

In the third model, we add Fertiliser as well as Soil and Variety as the third explanatory variable. 

The fit of Model 3 is a little better compared to Model 2 judging from the QQ plot. However, in a plot of the errors (residuals) by the fitted values, we can see that Model 3 fits much better than Model 2 (see plot below).


The left panel of the plot below is a scatter plot of the errors by the fitted values when just Soil is in the model. In the middle panel is when Soil and Variety are in the model, and the right panel is when all three variables are in the model. 
In the left and middle panel of the plot below, there is a distinct pattern, indicating that we need to add more variables to account for variability. In the right panel, the values are randomly distributed, indicating that more variability has been accounted for, and hence Model 3 looks to fit the data better than Model 1 or 2.
